content: Recently Drive has become a vehicle for abuse by Russian hackers, using it to bombard users with mentions and notifications in an attempt to get them to visit malicious websites. This has even going in for weeks without a solution, and Google employees have been incredibly unhelpful. content: I'm tired of this bug. And I'm pretty sure so is everyone with an Android device with Android 9 and newer. The Back Up Now button from Settings -> System -> Backup becomes inactive when you enable PIN/Fingerprint/Pattern on your phone. Also, the message above says "waiting to back up...". The second you disable that, the button becomes active again and can be used to make new backups. This is an issue starting with Android 9, still occurs with Android 10 (and probably 11, too). This also occurs with Pixel devices. Pretty much any Android device with Android 9 or newer, regardless of manufacturer. Please, fix this. I'd be happy to change my rating once you get this fixed. There are hundreds of people complaining about this. Still, nobody seems to care. You can just get an Android device with Android 9 or newer, enable PIN/Fingerprint/Pattern and check out that button. You'll see the bug right away. And no, uninstalling/disabling/clearing app cache & data doesn't do anything. However, it doesn't occur with Google One app. So...although, to me, this feels more like an Android bug than an app bug, I could be wrong. I just wanna say that, assuming this is an app bug, no Google Drive version fixed it so far.

Till i updated it to newer version, it was working good. Now, in the updated version, it has too bugs. content: Google broke Android Backup in Android 9 Pie. I HAVE THE ANSWER!!! Turn off all lockscreen security, pin, password, biometrics, then go to the backup screen and the backup button will now be blue. Hit the button and the backup will work normally. Be sure to turn your lockscreen security back on. Unfortunately you will need to reregister, aka retrain all your biometrics. I believe this problem began with the May 1, 2019 security patch to Android 9 Pie. Prior to this backup worked.

content: Would I recommend using Google Drive to others? I find no reason why anyone would want to give themselves headaches while producing no timely results after placing their personal or professional files into a vacuum. The world operates in real time in many ways thanks to the www, and internet speed is there for most people. So today I know of no one who finds convenience in and preference for doing a task on their list twice or multiple times, and no one would ever want to go through multiple processes just to be unsuccessful in the end with what they were trying to accomplish in terms of file storage, retrieval, or sharing of. We know this simply as waste of time, and that has precisely been my experience with Google Drive in recent time. Years ago, before intra-corporate hissy fits were witnessed between top giants on this playing field, user friendliness had much more of a presence, and was even the primary focus and goal for software and hardware product developers, however keeping in mind ease of use of a product escaped the buildings and minds of developers, who are unfortunately now so focused on exclusivity that no products work universally, like they used to in tech world, back when users were much happier in front of their computers. Today we see widespread frustration, and rare immediate success with trying to do something like send a file in an email that doesnâ€™t involve hours of ridiculous rigmarole, or just to try to review your own file that you already have on your computer so why on Earth would you want to download it again when opening it in Google Drive or any other cloud service? I know that the answer is to force a user then to enlist the uses of affiliates or that companyâ€™s other products and that lack of concern or even admittance to this strategy seems to be ever absent, while ignoring or disregarding users overall feelings of frustration, dissatisfaction, and unwillingness to go forward using anything from them, has largely become standard operating procedure. Consumers have the responsibility of rejecting this tactic and refusing to purchase and use products and company services as they continue with these practices, otherwise we give permission and allow corporate giants and other companies that will follow, to own and hold our personal information and to dictate how and when we can access this information belonging to us. This is basically personal information extortion and laws need to get current in preventing these ethically low standard practices as they do not benefit their users and are clearly no longer designed with us in mind.
